notes:
1. Definition

A watershed, also known as a catchment area or drainage basin, is an area of land where all the precipitation that falls on it drains to a common outlet. This outlet could be a point on a river, a lake, or the ocean.

The watershed is the fundamental unit of study in hydrology. It acts like a funnel, collecting all the water within its area and channeling it to a single point.

2. Drainage Divide

The boundary of a watershed is called the drainage divide. It is a line of high ground (like a ridge) that separates adjacent watersheds. A drop of rain falling on one side of the divide will flow to one watershed's outlet, while a drop falling on the other side will flow to a different outlet.

3. Delineating a Watershed

Watershed boundaries are determined from topographic maps, which show the elevation of the land using contour lines.

To delineate a watershed for a given outlet point:

  1. Identify the outlet point on the stream.
  2. Identify the high points (ridges) surrounding the stream.
  3. Draw the drainage divide line connecting these high points, ensuring the line is always perpendicular to the contour lines it crosses. Water flows downhill, perpendicular to contour lines.
